text: And say, because you have social distancing, you have plastic barriers, when you go to the cashier, you have separators between the booths.

text: Nothing.

speaker: Joe Biden

text: Thank you.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Thank you, George.
speaker: Audience Member 1

text: Thank you, Vice President Biden.
speaker: Audience Member 5

text: Nice to meet you.
speaker: Audience Member 5

text: What’s your view on the Crime Bill that you wrote 1994, which showed prejudice against minorities?
speaker: Audience Member 5

text: Where do you stand today on that?
speaker: Audience Member 5

text: Well, first of all, things have changed drastically.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: That Crime Bill, when it voted, the Black Caucus voted for it.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Every Black mayor supported it across the board and the Crime Bill itself did not have mandatory sentences except for two things.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: It had three strikes and you’re out, which I voted against, in the Crime Bill, but it had a lot of other things in it that turned out to be both bad and good.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: I wrote the Violence Against Women Act.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: That was part of the assault weapons ban and other things that were good.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: What I was against was giving states more money for prison systems that they could build, state prison systems.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: And you have 93 out of every 100 people in jail now is in a state prison, not in a federal prison, because they built more prisons.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: I also wrote into that bill a thing called drug courts.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: I don’t believe anybody should be going to jail for drug use.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: They should be going into mandatory rehabilitation.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: We should be building rehab centers to have these people housed.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: We should decriminalize marijuana, wipe out the record so you can actually say honesty, “You ever been arrested for murder for anything?” You can say no, because we’re going to pass a law saying there is no background that you have to reveal relative to the use of marijuana.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: And so there’s a lot of things.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: But in addition to that, we’ve got to change the system.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: I joined with a group of people in the House to provide for changing the system from punishment to rehabilitation.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Along with a guy named Marlon Specter, who you may remember, I wrote the Second Chance Act.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: In the meantime, an awful lot of people were jailed for minor drug crimes after the Crime Bill.
speaker: George Stephanopoulos

text: Right.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Was it a mistake to support it?
speaker: George Stephanopoulos

text: Yes, it was.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: But here’s where the mistake.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: The mistake came in terms of what the states did locally.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: What we did federally, we said, you remember, George, it was all about the same time for the same crime.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: What I had done as the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee, I took the 10 Circuit Courts of Appeals, took some really brilliant lawyers working for me in Judiciary, we did a study and we determined what happens if, for the first, second, third offense for any crime in the criminal justice system at the federal level, if you’re a Black man and it’s the first time you’ve committed robbery, how long would you go to jail?
speaker: Joe Biden

text: On average?
speaker: Joe Biden

text: If you’re White man, how long?
speaker: Joe Biden

text: The Black man would go to jail on average 13 years.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: White man, two years.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: I’d go down the list of every single crime.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: So we set up a sentencing commission.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: We didn’t set the time.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Every single solitary maximum was reduced in there.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: But what happened was it became the same time for the same crime.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: So it said, “You have to serve between one and three years.” And it ended up becoming much lower, Black folks went to jail a lot less than they would have before.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: But it was a mistake.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Let me ask another follow-up on the Crime bill.
speaker: George Stephanopoulos

text: It also funded 100,000 police back in 1994.

text: You’ve often said that more cops clearly mean less crime.

text: Do you still believe that?

text: Yes, if in fact they’re involved in community policing, not jump squads.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: For example, when we had community policing, from the mid-’90s on until till Bush got elected, what happened?
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Violent crime actually went down precipitous.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Remember the significant rise in violent crime that was occurring in the late ’80s into the ’90s.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: It went down and fewer African Americans were arrested because you had the requirement.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: The cops didn’t like it.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: They didn’t like the community policing, because you had to have two people in the vehicle, they had to get out of their cars, they had to introduce themselves to who own the local liquor store, who owned the local grocery store, who was the woman on the corner.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: And what they would do, George, they’d actually go and give people their phone numbers.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: A cop would give the phone number.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: So if Nelly Smith was on the second floor where drug deals took place and things happened below her apartment, she could call and say, “It’s Millie, and there’s something going on here.” And they’d never revealed it was her, because they’d know, if she knew that, in fact, they report, they’d never report the crime, she’d never report.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: So it actually started to come down.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: And what happened?
speaker: Joe Biden

text: They eliminated the funding for community policing.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Community policing doesn’t mean more people coming in, in armored Humvees and swarming.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: It turned out that by the time we got to the late ’90s and crime had come down so much, the mayors and everybody asked the question, “Where do you want me to spend the money?” They say, “Well, only 1% thought violent crime was a problem.” It was as high as 22%.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Right now we have a systemic problem.
speaker: George Stephanopoulos

text: How do you get the kind of policing, prevent the kind of policing [crosstalk 00:35:55].
speaker: George Stephanopoulos

text: You have to change the way in which they [inaudible 00:35:55].
speaker: Joe Biden

text: One of the things I’m going to do, George, is what is set up a national study group made up of cops, social workers, as well as made up of the Black community and the Brown community to sit down in the White House and over the next year come up with significant reforms that need to take place within communities.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: You have to bring them together.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: One of the things I’ve observed is, the neighborhood I grew up, I grew up in Claymont, you either became a cop, a firefighter, or a priest.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: I wasn’t qualified much to do any one of them, but here’s the deal, all kidding aside.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Most cops don’t like bad cops.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Correct.
speaker: Audience Member 5

text: They don’t like it.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: That’s correct.
speaker: Audience Member 5

text: And so what happens is they get intimidated into not reporting.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: So one of the things we do is there has to be transparency available.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: We have to be able to go in at the federal level, be able to go in and check out whether or not there’s systematic problems within police departments.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: If, in fact, a cop needs to be tried, it’s not the prosecutor in the community, in the district there.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: You’ve got to go outside the community to get another prosecutor to come in to handle the crime.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: There’s a lot of things we’ve learned, and it takes time but we can do this.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: You can ban choke holds, but beyond that, you have to teach people how to de-escalate circumstances.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: De-escalate.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: So instead of anybody coming at you and the first thing you do is shoot to kill, you shoot them in the leg.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: There’s ways you have to do more background checks in terms of whether or not the person coming in, passes a certain psychological test.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: And the last thing I’ll say, and I’m sorry, but it’s really, I think, really, really important, is you have to be in a position where you are able to identify, identify the things that have to change.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: And one of the things that has to change is so many cops get called into circumstances where somebody is mentally off.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Like what happened not long ago, that guy with the knife.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: That’s why we have to provide within police departments psychologists and social workers to go out with the cops on those calls, some of those 911 calls to de-escalate the circumstance, to deal with talking them down.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: But cops are kind of like school teachers now.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: A school teacher has to know everything from how to handle hunger in a household as well as how to teach how to read.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: Well, cops or don’t have that breadth, and there’s a lot of things we can do.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: We shouldn’t be defunding cops.
speaker: Joe Biden

text: We should be mandating the things that we should be doing within police departments and make sure there’s total transparency.

text: We were just hitting 160 million jobs, companies are pouring into our nation because of the tax rate, and if Biden comes in and raises taxes on everybody, including middle income taxes, which he wants to do, you will blow this thing, and you’ll end up with a depression, the likes of which you’ve never had.

text: That’s what’s going to happen.

text: We have something that’s really good.

text: They’re not the lowest, but they’re among the lowest.

text: And what that means, is jobs, but also we’re doing a very big, and we’ve done a very big, middle income tax package.

text: So if we get in, we’re going to do the middle income tax package, but it’s a great question.

speaker: Donald Trump

text: They have to come in legally.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: But we are working very hard on the DACA program.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: And you will be, I think, very happy over the course of the next year.

text: Thank you.

text: Because I feel the same way as you do about it.

text: Thank you, Mr. President.

text: Thank you.

text: Thank you very much.

text: Mr. President, in point of fact, the DACA program… Under your administration, no new applicants are allowed.

text: And in fact, the DACA recipients now have to renew every year as opposed to every two years.

text: So in fact, the DACA program has been curtailed by your administration.

text: And we’ve made it very, very difficult to come in because of the pandemic, and other reasons, and crime.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: But we have a very strong border right now, and we have to keep it that way.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: But we want people to come into our country, but they have to come in through a merit system, and they have to come in legally.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: And people are very, very happy with it.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: You haven’t heard any complaints about that.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: But what happened is because of the pandemic, we have to be extra cautious.

text: You have been promising this immigration bill since, well, at least July, when you told my colleague on Telemundo it was coming.

text: But nothing’s come yet.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: It’s very happy.

text: The fact is, we got rid of catch and release, which is a disaster.

text: You catch somebody.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: They could be a murderer.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: That could be a rapist, and we’re supposed to release them into our country.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: These are the laws that I inherited.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: We ended that program.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: Now, I think you’re going to see something very, very good.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: The whole immigration… If you look at what’s going on, people used to pour into our country.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: And especially during the pandemic, I think even you, Savannah, will be very impressed with what we’ve done.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: Sir, we have about 30 seconds left.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: Sure.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: I think about people sitting out there tonight.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: There are some who love you.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: Some of them are sitting right around here, and some who will never vote for you.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: But there are people in the middle.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: There are people who aren’t sure.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: That’s right.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: There are people who want to know why they should give you a second chance and how you might improve in a second term.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: 30 seconds.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: What would you say to them?
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: Because I’ve done a great job.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: We have the strongest economy in the world.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: We closed it up.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: We are coming around the corner.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: The vaccines are coming out soon, and our economy is strong.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: We are at a level with jobs like we’ve never been before.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: We’ve rebuilt our military.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: We’ve rebuilt our borders.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: We had no borders.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: We had no nothing.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: We’ve rebuilt so much.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: We’ve given you the greatest tax cut in the history of our country.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: Greatest regulation cut, equally as important.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: And we created new levels of jobs that nobody thought was possible.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: And next year is going to be better than ever before.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: I got to leave it there.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: I got a wrap from the control room.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: Mr. President, thank you for your time.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: Thank you very much.
speaker: Donald Trump

text: Thank you for listening to the voters’ questions.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: That concludes our town hall.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: We do want to thank the president again, as well as our audience in hot Miami, and all of you watching at home.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: And a reminder, Donald Trump and Joe Biden are scheduled to meet in person a week from tonight in Nashville, a second and final presidential debate, moderated by our own Kristen Welker.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: Have a good evening, and thanks for being with us.
speaker: Savannah Guthrie

text: Senator Harris and Vice President Pence, thank you for being here.
speaker: Susan Page

text: We’re meeting as President Trump and the First Lady continue to undergo treatment in Washington, after testing positive for COVID-19.
speaker: Susan Page

text: We send our thoughts and prayers to them for their rapid and complete recovery, and for the recovery of everyone afflicted by the coronavirus.
speaker: Susan Page

text: The two campaigns and the commission on presidential debates agreed to the ground rules for tonight.
speaker: Susan Page

text: I’m here to enforce them.On behalf of the millions of Americans who are watching.
speaker: Susan Page

text: One note: no one in either campaign or at the commission or anywhere else has been told in advance what topics I’ll raise or what questions I’ll ask.
speaker: Susan Page

text: This 90 minute debate will be divided into nine segments of about 10 minutes each.
speaker: Susan Page

text: I’ll begin a segment by posing a question to each of you.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Sometimes the same question, sometimes a different question on the same topic.
speaker: Susan Page

text: You will then have two minutes to answer without interruption by me or the other candidate.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Then we’ll take six minutes or so to discuss the issue.
speaker: Susan Page

text: At that point, although there will always be more to say, we’ll move on to the next topic.
speaker: Susan Page

text: We want a debate that is lively, but Americans also deserve a discussion that is civil.
speaker: Susan Page

text: These are tumultuous times, but we can and will have a respectful exchange about the big issues facing our nation.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Let’s begin with the ongoing pandemic that has cost our country so much.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Senator Harris, the coronavirus is not under control.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Over the past week, Johns Hopkins reports that 39 states have had more COVID cases over the past seven days than in the week before.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Nine States have set new records.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Even if a vaccine is released soon, the next administration will face hard choices.
speaker: Susan Page

text: What would a Biden administration do in January and February that a Trump administration wouldn’t do?
speaker: Susan Page

text: Would you impose new lockdowns for businesses and schools and hotspots, a federal mandate to wear masks?
speaker: Susan Page

text: You have two minutes to respond without interruption.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Thank you, Susan.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Well, the American people have witnessed what is the greatest failure of any presidential administration in the history of our country.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And here are the facts.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: 210,000 dead people in our country in just the last several months.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Over 7 million people who have contracted this disease.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: One in five businesses closed.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We’re looking at frontline workers who have been treated like sacrificial workers.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We are looking at over 30 million people, who in the last several months, had to file for unemployment.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And here’s the thing, on January 28th, the vice president and the president were informed about the nature of this pandemic.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: They were informed that it’s lethal in consequence, that it is airborne, that it will affect young people, and that it would be contracted because it is airborne.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And they knew what was happening, and they didn’t tell you.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Can you imagine if you knew on January 28th, as opposed to March 13th, what they knew, what you might’ve done to prepare?
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: They knew, and they covered it up.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: The president said it was a hoax.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: They minimized the seriousness of it.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: The president said, “You’re on one side of his ledger if you wear a mask.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: You’re on the other side of his ledger if you don’t.” And in spite of all of that, today, they still don’t have a plan.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: They still don’t have a plan.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Well, Joe Biden does.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And our plan is about what we need to do around a national strategy for contact tracing, for testing, for administration of the vaccine, and making sure that it will be free for all.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: That is the plan that Joe Biden has and that I have, knowing that we have to get a hold of what has been going on, and we need to save our country.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And Joe Biden is the best leader to do that.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And frankly, this administration has forfeited their-
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you, Senator Harris-
speaker: Susan Page

text: … right to reelection based on this.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you, Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Vice President Pence, more than 210,000 Americans have died of COVID-19 since February.
speaker: Susan Page

text: The US death toll, as a percentage of our population, is higher than that of almost every other wealthy nation on Earth.
speaker: Susan Page

text: For instance, our death rate is two and a half times that of Canada, next door.
speaker: Susan Page

text: You had the administration’s coronavirus task force.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Why is the US death toll, as a percentage of our population, higher than that of almost every other wealthy country?
speaker: Susan Page

text: And you have two minutes to respond without interruption.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Susan, thank you.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And I want to thank the Commission and the University of Utah for hosting this event.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And Senator Harris, it’s a privilege to be on the stage with you.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And our nation has gone through a very challenging time this year.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But I want the American people to know that from the very first day, President Donald Trump has put the health of America first.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Before there were more than five cases in the United States, all people who had returned from China, President Donald Trump did what no other American president had ever done.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And that was, he suspended all travel from China, the second largest economy in the world.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Now, Senator Joe Biden opposed that decision.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: He said it was xenophobic and hysterical.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But I can tell you having led the white house coronavirus task force that that decision alone by President Trump bought us invaluable time to stand up the greatest national mobilization since World War Two.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And I believe it saved hundreds of thousands of American lives.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Because with that time, we were able to reinvent testing.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: More than 115 million tests had been done to date.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: We were able to see to the delivery of billions of supplies, so our doctors and nurses had the resources support they needed.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And we began, really, before the month of February we started to develop a vaccine and to develop medicines and therapeutics that have been saving lives all along the way.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And under President Trump’s leadership, Operation Warp Speed, we believe we’ll have literally tens of millions of doses of a vaccine before the end of this year.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: The reality is, when you look at the Biden plan, it reads an awful lot like what President Trump, and I, and our task force has been doing every step of the way.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And quite frankly, when I look at their plan that talks about advancing testing, creating new PPE, developing a vaccine, it looks a little bit like plagiarism, which is something Joe Biden knows a little bit about.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And I think the American people know that this is a president who has put the health-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, Vice President Pence-
speaker: Susan Page

text: … of America first.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And the American people, I believe with my heart, can be proud-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, Vice President Pence-
speaker: Susan Page

text: … of the sacrifices they have made.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: It’s saved countless American lives-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, Vice President Pence.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Senator Harris, would you like to respond?
speaker: Susan Page

text: Absolutely.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Whatever the vice president is claiming the administration has done, clearly, it hasn’t worked.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: When you’re looking at over 210,000 dead bodies in our country, American lives that have been lost, families that are grieving that loss, and the vice president is the head of the task force and knew on January 28th, how serious this was.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And then, thanks to Bob Woodward, we learned that they knew about it.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And then when that was exposed, the vice president said, when asked, “Well, why didn’t you all tell anybody?” He said, “Because the president wanted people to remain calm.”
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Well, let’s [crosstalk 00:07:53]-
speaker: Susan Page

text: No.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: But Susan, this is important.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And I want to add-
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Susan, I have to weigh in here-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Mr. Vice President, I’m speaking.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I have to weigh in.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I’m speaking.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: You can have 15 more seconds, and then we’ll give the vice-president a chance to respond-
speaker: Susan Page

text: Thank you.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: So I want to ask the American people, how calm were you when you were panicked about where you were going to get your next roll of toilet paper?
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: How calm were you when your kids were sent home from school and you didn’t know when they could go back?
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: How calm were you-
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you-
speaker: Susan Page

text: … when your children-
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you, Senator Harris-
speaker: Susan Page

text: … couldn’t see your parents because you were afraid they could kill them.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Let’s give Vice President Pence a chance to respond.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Vice President Pence, you have one minute to respond.
speaker: Susan Page

text: There’s not a day gone by that I haven’t thought of every American family that’s lost a loved one.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And I want all of you to know that you’ll always be in our hearts and in our prayers.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But when you say what the American people have done over these last eight months, hasn’t worked, that’s a great disservice to the sacrifices the American people have made-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I’m referring to the president-
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: But the reality… If I may finish, Senator.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: The reality is Dr. Fauci said everything that he told the president in the Oval Office, the president told the American.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Now President Trump, I will tell you, has boundless confidence in the American people, and he always spoke with confidence that we’d get through this together.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But when you say it hasn’t worked… When Dr. Fauci, and Dr. Birx, and our medical experts came to us in the second week of March, they said, if the president didn’t take the unprecedented step of shutting down roughly half of the American economy, that we could lose 2.2 million Americans.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: That’s the reality.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you, Vice President Pence-
speaker: Susan Page

text: They also said to us, if we did everything right, Susan, we could still lose more than 200,000 Americans.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Vice President Pence-
speaker: Susan Page

text: One life lost is too many, Susan.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But the American people, I believe, deserve credit for the sacrifices that they have made, putting the health of their family and their neighbors first, our doctors, our nurses, our first responders.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, Vice President Pence.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And I’m going to speak up on behalf of what the American people have done.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Vice President Pence, you were in the front row in a Rose Garden event 11 days ago, at what seems to have been a super spreader event for senior administration and congressional officials.
speaker: Susan Page

text: No social distancing, few masks, and now a cluster of coronavirus cases among those who were there.
speaker: Susan Page

text: How can you expect Americans to follow the administration…
speaker: Susan Page

text: How can you expect Americans to follow the administration’s safety guidelines to protect themselves from COVID when you at the White House have not been doing so?
speaker: Susan Page

text: Well, the American people have demonstrated over the last eight months, that when given the facts, they’re willing to put the health of their families and their neighbors and people they don’t even know first.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: President Trump and I have great confidence in the American people and their ability to take that information and put it into practice.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: In the height of the epidemic when we were losing a heartbreaking number of 2,500 Americans a day, we surged resources to New Jersey and New York and New Orleans and Detroit.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: We told the American people what needed to be done, and the American people made the sacrifices.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: When the outbreak in the Sun Belt happened this summer, again, Americans stepped forward.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But the reality is the work of the President of the United States goes on.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: A vacancy on the Supreme Court of the United States has come upon us, and the President introduced Judge Amy Coney Barrett.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Yes, thank you.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Thank you, Vice President.
speaker: Susan Page

text: If I may say, that Rose Garden event, been a great deal of speculation about it.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: My wife, Karen and I were there and honored to be there.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Many of the people who were at that event, Susan, actually were tested for Coronavirus, and it was an outdoor event, which all of our scientists regularly and routinely advise.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: The difference here is President Trump and I trust the American people to make choices in the best interest of their health.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Joe Biden and Kamala Harris consistently talk about mandates, and not just mandates with the Coronavirus, but a government takeover of healthcare, the Green New Deal, all government control.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: We’re about freedom and respecting the freedom of the American people.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Let’s talk about respecting the American people.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: You respect the American people when you tell them the truth.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: You respect the American people when you have the courage to be a leader.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Which we’ve always done.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Speaking of those things that you may not want people to hear, but they need to hear so they can protect themselves.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: But this administration stood on information that, if you had as a parent, if you had as a worker, knowing you didn’t have enough money saved up, and now you’re standing in a food line because of the ineptitude of a administration that was unwilling to speak the truth to the American people.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: So let’s talk about caring about the American people.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: The American people have had to sacrifice far too much because of the incompetence of this administration.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: It is asking too much of the people-
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Susan, we talked about this.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: It is asking too much of the people.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: That they would not be equipped with the information they need to help themselves to protect their parents and their children.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I’m sorry.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Kamala Harris, Senator Harris, I mean, I’m sorry.
speaker: Susan Page

text: That’s fine, I’m Kamala.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: No, no, you’re Senator Harris to me.
speaker: Susan Page

text: For life to get back to normal, Dr. Anthony Fauci and other experts say that most of the people who can be vaccinated need to be vaccinated.
speaker: Susan Page

text: But half of Americans now say they wouldn’t take a vaccine if it was released now.
speaker: Susan Page

text: If the Trump administration approves a vaccine before or after the election, should Americans take it, and would you take it?
speaker: Susan Page

text: If the public health professionals, if Dr. Fauci, if the doctors tell us that we should take it, I’ll be the first in line to take it, absolutely.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: But if Donald Trump tells us that we should take it, I’m not taking it.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Vice President Pence, there’ve been a lot of repercussions from this pandemic.
speaker: Susan Page

text: In recent days, the President’s diagnosis of COVID-19 has underscored the importance of the job that you hold and that you are seeking.
speaker: Susan Page

text: That’s our second topic tonight.
speaker: Susan Page

text: It’s the role of the Vice President.
speaker: Susan Page

text: One of you will make history on January 20th.
speaker: Susan Page

text: You will be the Vice President to the oldest President the United States has ever had.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Donald Trump will be 74 years old on inauguration day.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Joe Biden will be 78 years old.
speaker: Susan Page

text: That already has raised concerns among some voters, concerns that have been sharpened by President Trump’s hospitalization in recent days.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Vice President Pence, have you had a conversation or reached an agreement with President Trump about safeguards or procedures when it comes to the issue of presidential disability?
speaker: Susan Page

text: And if not, do you think you should?
speaker: Susan Page

text: You have two minutes without interruption.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Well, Susan, thank you.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Although, I would like to go back.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I think we need to move on to the issue of vice presidency.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Well, thank you, but I would like to go back because the reality is that we’re going to have a vaccine, Senator, in record time.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: In unheard of time, in less than a year.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: We have five companies in phase three clinical trials.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And we’re right now producing tens of millions of doses.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: So the fact that you continue to undermine public confidence in a vaccine, if the vaccine emerges during the Trump administration, I think is unconscionable.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And Senator, I just ask you, stop playing politics with people’s lives.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: The reality is that we will have a vaccine, we believe, before the end of this year.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And it will have the capacity to save countless American lives.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And your continuous undermining of confidence in a vaccine is just, it’s unacceptable.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And let me also say, the reality is, when you talk about failure in this administration, we actually do know what failure looks like in a pandemic.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: It was 2009.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: The Swine flu arrived in the United States.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thankfully, it ended up not being as lethal as the Coronavirus.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But before the end of the year, when Joe Biden was Vice President of the United States, not seven and a half million people contracted the Swine flu, 60 million Americans contracted the Swine flu.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: If the Swine flu had been as lethal as the Coronavirus in 2009 when Joe Biden was Vice President, we would have lost 2 million American lives.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: His own chief of staff, Ron Klain would say last year that it was pure luck that they did, “Everything possible wrong.” And we learned from that.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: They left the strategic national stockpile empty.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: They left an empty and hollow plan, but we still learn from it, and I think the American people, I’m going to say again, can be proud of what we have done.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And Senator, please stop undermining confidence in a vaccine.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Senator Harris, let me ask you the same question that I asked her Vice President Pence, which is, have you had a conversation or reached an agreement with Vice President Biden about safeguards or procedures when it comes to the issue of presidential disability?
speaker: Susan Page

text: And if not, and if you win the election next month, do you think you should?
speaker: Susan Page

text: You have two minutes uninterrupted.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Let me tell you first of all, the day I got the call from Joe Biden, it was actually a Zoom call, asking me to serve with him on this ticket was probably one of the most memorable days of my life.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I thought about my mother, who came to the United States at the age of 19, gave birth to me at the age of 25 at Kaiser Hospital in Oakland, California.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And the thought that I’d be sitting here right now, I know, would make her proud.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And she must be looking down on this.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Joe and I were raised in a very similar way.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We were raised with values that are about hard work, about the value and the dignity of public service, and about the importance of fighting for the dignity of all people.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And I think Joe asked me to serve with him because I have a career that included being elected the first woman District Attorney of San Francisco, where I created models of innovation for law enforcement, in terms of reform of the criminal justice system.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I was elected the first woman of color, and black woman to be elected Attorney General of the state of California, where I ran the second largest department of justice in the United States.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Second only to the United States Department of Justice.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And there, I took on everything from transnational criminal organizations, to the big banks that were taking advantage of homeowners, to for-profit colleges that were taking advantage of veterans.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And then of course, now I serve in the United States Senate as only the second black woman ever elected to the United States Senate.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I serve on the Senate Intelligence Committee where I’ve been in regular receipt of classified information about threats to our nation in hotspots around the world.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I’ve traveled the world, I’ve met with our soldiers in war zones.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And I think Joe has asked me to serve with him because he knows that we share a purpose, which is about lifting up the American people.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And after the four years that we have seen of Donald Trump unifying our country around our common values and principles.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you, Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Neither President Trump, nor Vice President Biden has released a sort of detailed health information that had become the modern norm until the 2016 election.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And in recent days, President Trump’s doctors have given misleading answers, or refused to answer basic questions about his health.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And my question to each of you in turn is, is this information voters deserve to know?
speaker: Susan Page

text: Vice President Pence, would you like to go first?
speaker: Susan Page

text: Well, Susan, thank you.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And let me say on behalf of the President and the First Lady, how moved we’ve all been by the outpouring of prayers and concern for the President.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And I do believe it’s emblematic of the prayers and the concern that have ushered forth for every American impacted by the Coronavirus.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But the care of the President received at Walter Reed Hospital, the White House doctors was exceptional.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And the transparency that they practiced all along the way will continue.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: The American people have a right to know about-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: … they will continue.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: The American people have a right to know about the health and well-being of their president, and we’ll continue to do that.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But I’m just extremely grateful and was more than a little moved by the broad and bipartisan support.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And Senator, I want to thank you and Joe Biden for your expressions and genuine concern.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And I also want to congratulate you, as I did on that phone call, on the historic nature of your nomination.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I never expected to be on this stage four years ago, so I know the feeling, but the reality is we’ve got an election before the American people in the midst of this challenging year and the stakes have never been higher, but I think the choice has never been here.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, Vice President.
speaker: Susan Page

text: I want to give Senator Harris a chance to respond to the same question I asked, which is, do voters have a right to know more detailed health information about presidential candidates and especially about presidents, especially when they’re facing some kind of challenge?
speaker: Susan Page

text: Absolutely.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And that’s why Joe Biden has been so incredibly transparent.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And certainly by contrast that the President has not, both in terms of health records, but also let’s look at taxes.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We now know because of great investigative journalism that Donald Trump paid $750 in taxes.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: When I first heard about it, I literally said, “You mean $750,000?” And it was like no, $750.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We now know Donald Trump owes and is in debt for $400 million.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And just so everyone is clear, when we say in debt, it means you owe money to somebody.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And it’d be really good to know who the President of the United States, the commander-in-chief owes money to because the American people have a right to know what is influencing the President’s decisions.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And is he making those decisions on the best interest of the American people, of you or self-interest?
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: So, Susan, I’m glad you asked about transparency because it has to be across the board.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Joe has been incredibly transparent over many, many years.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: The one thing we all know about Joe, he puts it all out there.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: He is honest, he is forthright, but Donald Trump on the other hand has been about covering up everything.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Susan, Susan-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: I want to give you a chance to respond, Vice President.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Well, look, I respect the fact that Joe Biden spent 47 years in public life.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I respect your public service as well.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: The American people have a president who was a businessman, he’s a job creator.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Who’s paid tens of millions of dollars in taxes, payroll taxes, property taxes.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: He’s created tens of thousands of American jobs.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And the President said those public reports are not accurate.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And the President’s also released literally stacks of financial disclosures the American people can review just as the law allows.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But the distinction here is that Joe Biden, 47 years in public service compared to President Donald Trump, who brought all of that experience four years ago-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you Vice President-
speaker: Susan Page

text: … and turned this economy around by cutting taxes, rolling back regulations-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, Vice President Pence-
speaker: Susan Page

text: … unleashing American energy, fighting for free and fair trade.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And all of that’s on the line-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you Vice President Pence-
speaker: Susan Page

text: … if Joe Biden and Kamala Harris are elected.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: That’s a good segue into our third topic-
speaker: Susan Page

text: That’s a great segue.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: … which is about the economy.
speaker: Susan Page

text: This has been another aspect of life for Americans, it’s been so affected by this coronavirus.
speaker: Susan Page

text: We have a jobs crisis brewing.
speaker: Susan Page

text: On Friday, we learned that the unemployment rate had declined to seven point nine percent in September, but the job growth had stalled.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And that was before the latest round of layoffs and furloughs in the airline industry, at Disney, and elsewhere.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Hundreds of thousands of discouraged workers have stopped looking for work.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Nearly 11 million jobs that existed at the beginning of the year haven’t been replaced.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Those hardest hit include Latinos, Blacks, and women.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Senator Harris, the Biden, Harris campaign has proposed new programs to boost the economy.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And you would pay for that new spending by raising four trillion dollars in taxes on wealthy individuals and corporations.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Some economists warn that could curb entrepreneurial ventures that fuel growth and create jobs.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Would raising taxes put the recovery at risk?
speaker: Susan Page

text: And you have two minutes to answer uninterrupted.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Thank you.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: On the issue of the economy, I think there couldn’t be a more fundamental difference between Donald Trump and Joe Biden.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Joe Biden believes you measure the health and the strength of America’s economy based on the health and the strength of the American worker and the American family.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: On the other hand, you have Donald Trump who measures the strength of the economy based on how rich people are doing, which is why he passed a tax bill benefiting the top one percent and the biggest corporations of America, leading to a two trillion dollar deficit that the American people are going to have to pay for.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: On day one, Joe Biden will repeal that tax bill, he’ll get rid of it.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And what he’ll do with the money is invest it in the American people.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And through a plan that is about investing in infrastructure, something that Donald Trump said he would do, I remember hearing about some infrastructure week, I don’t think it ever happened, but Joe Biden will do that.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: He’ll invest in infrastructure.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: It’s about upgrading our roads and bridges, but also investing in clean energy and renewable energy.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Joe was going to invest that money in what we need to do around innovation.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: There was a time when our country believed in science and invested in research and development, so that we were an innovation leader on the globe.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Joe Biden will use that money to invest in education.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: So for example, for folks who want to go to a two-year community college, it will be free.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: If you come from a family that makes less than $125,000, you’ll go to a public university for free.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And across the board, we’ll make sure that if you have student loan debt, it’s cut by $10,000.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: That’s how Joe Biden thinks about the economy which is, it’s about investing in the people of our country.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: As opposed to passing a tax bill, which had the benefit of letting American corporations go off-shore to do their business.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: You’re welcome.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Vice President Pence, your administration has been predicting a rapid and robust recovery, but the latest economic report suggests that’s not happening.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Should Americans be braced for an economic comeback that is going to take not months, but a year or more?
speaker: Susan Page

text: You have two minutes to answer uninterrupted.
speaker: Susan Page

text: When President Trump and I took office, America had gone through the slowest economic recovery since the Great Depression.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: It was when Joe Biden was vice president, they tried to tax and spend, and regulate, and bail our way back to a growing economy.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: President Trump cut taxes across the board.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Despite what Senator Harris says, the average American family of four had $2,000 in savings in taxes.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And with the rise in wages that occurred, most predominantly for blue collar, hardworking Americans, the average household income for a family of four increased by $4,000 following President Trump’s tax cuts.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But America, you just heard Senator Harris tell you, on day one, Joe Biden’s going to raise your taxes.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: It’s really remarkable to think-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: That’s not what I said.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I mean, right after a time where we’re going through a pandemic that lost 22 million jobs at the height, we’ve already added back 11.6 million jobs because we had a president who cut taxes, rolled back regulation, unleashed American energy, fought for free and fair trade and secured four trillion dollars from the Congress of the United States to give direct payments to families, save 50 million jobs through the Paycheck Protection Program.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: We literally have spared no expense to help the American people and the American worker through this.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Joe Biden and Kamala Harris want to raise taxes.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: They want to bury our economy under a two trillion dollar Green New Deal, which you were one of the original co-sponsors of in the United States Senate.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: They want to abolish fossil fuels and ban fracking, which would cost hundreds of thousands of Amercian jobs all across the heart land.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And Joe Biden wants to go back to the economic surrender to China, that when took office, half of our international trade deficit was with China alone.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And Joe Biden wants to repeal all of the tarrifs, that President Trump put into effect to fight for American jobs and American workers.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Joe Biden says democracy is on the ballot.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Make no mistake about it, Susan.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And the American economy, the American comeback is on the ballot with four more years of growth and opportunity.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you-
speaker: Susan Page

text: … and four more years of president Donald Trump, 2021-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, Vice President-
speaker: Susan Page

text: … is going to be the biggest economic year in the history of this country.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, Vice President Pence, Senator Harris.

text: Well, I mean, I thought we saw enough of it in last week’s debate, but I think this is supposed to be a debate based on fact and truth and the truth and the fact is, Joe Biden has been very clear, he will not raise taxes on anybody who makes less than $400,000 a year.

text: Okay.

text: And now that Trump-
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: … for the Recovery Act that brought America back, and now the Trump-Pence administration wants to take credit when they rode the coattails of Joe Biden’s success for the economy that they had at the beginning of their term.

text: This is what they’ve been doing.

text: In March, Breonna Taylor, a 26 year old emergency room technician in Louisville was shot and killed after police officers executing a search warrant in an aquatics investigation, broke into her apartment.
speaker: Susan Page

text: The police said they identified themselves.

text: Taylor’s boyfriend said he didn’t hear them do that.
speaker: Susan Page

text: He used a gun registered to him to fire a shot, which wounded an officer.
speaker: Susan Page

text: The officers then fired more than 20 rounds into the apartment.
speaker: Susan Page

text: They say they were acting in self-defense.
speaker: Susan Page

text: None of them have been indicted in connection with her death.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Senator Harris, in the case of Breonna Taylor was justice done?
speaker: Susan Page

text: You have two minutes.

text: I don’t believe so.

text: And I’ve talked with Breonna’s mother, Tamika Palmer and her family and her family deserves justice.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: She was a beautiful young woman.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: She had as her life goal to become a nurse and she wanted to become an EMT to first learn what’s going on out on the street so she could then become a nurse and save lives.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And her life was taken justifiably and tragically and violently.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And it brings me to the eight minutes and 46 seconds that America witnessed during which an American man was tortured and killed under the knee of an armed uniformed police officer.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And people around our country of every race, of every age, of every gender, perfect strangers to each other, marched shoulder to shoulder, arm in arm, fighting for us to finally achieve that ideal of equal justice under law.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And I was a part of those peaceful protests.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And I believe strongly that first of all, we are never going to condone violence, but we always must fight for the values that we hold dear, including the fight to achieve our ideals.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And that’s why Joe Biden and I have said on this subject, look, and I’m a former career prosecutor.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I know what I’m talking about.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Bad cops are bad for good cops.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We need reform of our policing in America and our criminal justice system, which is why Joe and I will immediately ban choke holes and carotid holes.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: George Floyd would be alive today if we did that.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We will require a national registry for police officers who break the law.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We will, on the issue of criminal justice reform, get rid of private prisons and cash bail and we will decriminalize marijuana.

text: Thank you.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you, Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And we will expunge the records of those who have been convicted of marijuana.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: This is a time for leadership-

text: Thank you, Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: on a tragic, tragic issue-
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Senator Harris, your time is up.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Of honor on Black people in America who [crosstalk 00:34:11].
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you, Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Vice President Pence, let me pose the same question to you.
speaker: Susan Page

text: In the case of Breonna Taylor, was justice done?
speaker: Susan Page

text: You have two minutes uninterrupted.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Well, our heart breaks for the loss of any innocent American life and the family of Breonna Taylor has our sympathies.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But I trust our justice system, a grand jury that refuse the evidence.

text: But you’re entitled to your opinion, Senator.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I think, and with regard to George Floyd, there’s no excuse for what happened to George Floyd.

text: Justice will be served, but there’s also no excuse for the rioting and looting that followed.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I mean, it really is astonishing.

text: Flora Westbrook is with us here tonight in Salt Lake city.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Just a few weeks ago, I stood at what used to be her salon, it was burned to the ground by rioters and looters.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And Flora is still trying to put her life back together.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And I must tell you, this presumption that you hear consistently from Joe Biden and Kamala Harris, that America is systemically racist, and that as Joe Biden said that he believes that law enforcement has an implicit bias against minorities is a great insult to the men and women who serve in law enforcement.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And I want everyone to know who puts on the uniform of law enforcement every day, President Trump and I stand with you.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And it is remarkable that when Senator Tim Scott tried to pass a police reform bill, brought together a group of Republicans and Democrats, Senator Harris, you got up and walked out of the room and then you filibustered Senator Tim Scott’s bill on the Senate floor that would have provided new accountability, new repeat resources.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: We don’t have to choose between supporting law enforcement, proving public safety and supporting our African-American neighbors and all of our minorities.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Under President Trump’s leadership-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, Vice President.
speaker: Susan Page

text: We’ll always stand with law enforcement and we’ll do what we’ve done-
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Vice President Pence, thank you.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Your time is up.
speaker: Susan Page

text: From day one, it is improve the lives of African-Americans, record unemployment, record investments in education.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, Vice President Pence.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Vice President Pence, your time is up.
speaker: Susan Page

text: We’ll fight for school choice for all of [crosstalk 00:36:46].
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I’d like to respond.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: I will not sit here and be lectured by the Vice President on what it means to enforce the laws of our country.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: The only one on this stage, who has personally prosecuted everything from child sexual assault to homicide.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I’m the only one on this stage who has prosecuted the big banks for taking advantage of America’s homeowners.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I am the only one on this stage who prosecuted for-profit colleges for taking advantage of our veterans.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And the reality of this is that we are talking about an election in 27 days where last week the President of the United States took a debate stage in front of 70 million Americans and refused to condemn white supremacists.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Not.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Not true.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And it wasn’t like he didn’t have a chance.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: He didn’t do it.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And then he doubled down.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And then he said, “when pressed, stand back, stand by.” And this is a part of a pattern of Donald Trump’s.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: He called Mexicans rapists and criminals.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: He instituted as his first act, a Muslim ban.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: He on the issue of Charlottesville, where people were peacefully protesting the need for racial justice, where a young woman was killed.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And on the other side, there were neo-Nazis carrying Tiki torches, shouting racial epithets, anti-Semitic slurs.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And Donald Trump when asked about it said, “There were fine people on both sides.” This is who we have as the President of the United States and America, you deserve better.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Joe Biden will be a president who brings our country together-
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And recognizes the beauty in our diversity and the fact that we all have so much more in common than what separates us.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Vice President let me give you a minute to respond.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Thank you, Susan.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: I appreciate that very much.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I think this is one of the things that makes people dislike the media so much in this country, Susan, is that you selectively edit just like Senator Harris did, comments that President Trump and I and others on our side made.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I mean, Senator Harris conveniently admitted after the President made comments about people on either side of the debate over monuments, he condemned the KKK, neo-Nazis and white supremacists and has done so repeatedly.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: You’re concerned that he doesn’t condemn neo-Nazis.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: President Trump has Jewish grandchildren.

text: His daughter and son-in-law are Jewish.

text: Thank you.

text: Thank you, sir.

text: Thank you.

text: There is no more important issue than the final issue that we’re going to talk about tonight and that is the issue of the election itself.

text: But he attacked my record.

text: I would like an opportunity to respond to.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Let me give you 30 seconds because we’re running out of time.

text: I appreciate that.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: First of all, having served as the Attorney General of the state of California, the work that I did is a model of what our nation needs to do, and we will be able to do under a Joe Biden presidency.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Our agenda includes what this administration has failed to do.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: It will be about not only instituting a ban on choke holes and carotid holes-
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: I would like to go through-
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: These are points that you made earlier in the hour.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And I want to talk about the election itself before we have to [crosstalk 00:41:13].
speaker: Susan Page

text: But I want to talk about the connection between what Joe and I will do in my record, which includes I was the first statewide officer to institute a requirement that my agents would wear body cameras and keep them on full-time.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We were the first to initiate a requirement that there would be a training for law enforcement on implicit bias because yes, Joe Biden and I recognize that implicit bias does exist, Mr. Vice President, contrary to what you may believe.

text: We did the work of instituting reforms that were about investing in re-entry.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: This is the work that we have done and the work we will do going forward.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And again, I will not be lectured by the Vice President on our record of what we have done in terms of law enforcement and keeping our community safe and a commitment to reforming the criminal justice system of America.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you, Senator-
speaker: Susan Page

text: And a commitment to reforming the criminal justice system of America.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you, Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And I’d like you to respond first to the question on our final topic, the election itself.
speaker: Susan Page

text: President Trump has several times refused to commit himself to a peaceful transfer of power after the election.
speaker: Susan Page

text: If your ticket wins and president Trump refuses to accept a peaceful transfer of power, what steps would you and vice president Biden then take?
speaker: Susan Page

text: What would happen next?
speaker: Susan Page

text: You have two minutes.
speaker: Susan Page

text: So I’ll tell you.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Joe and I are particularly proud of the coalition that we’ve built around our campaign.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We probably have one of the broadest coalitions of folks that you’ve ever seen in a presidential race.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Of course, we have the support of Democrats, but also independents and Republicans.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: In fact, seven members of president George W. Bush’s cabinet are supporting our ticket.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We have the support of Colin Powell, Cindy McCain, John Kasich.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Over 500 generals, retired generals and former national security experts and advisors are supporting our campaign.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And I believe they are doing that because they know that Joe Biden has a deep, deep seated commitment to fight for our democracy, and to fight for the integrity of our democracy, and to bring integrity back to the White House.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We believe in the American people, we believe in our democracy, and here’s what I’d like to say to everybody.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Vote, please vote, vote early, come up with a plan to vote, go to Iwillvote.com.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: You can also go to Joebiden.com.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: We have it within our power in these next 27 days to make the decision about what will be the course of our country for the next four years.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And it is within our power, and if we use our vote and we use our voice, we will win.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And we will not let anyone subvert our democracy with what Donald Trump has been doing as he did on the debate stage last week, when, again, in front of 70 million people, he openly attempted to suppress the vote.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Joe Biden, on the other hand, on that same debate stage, because clearly Donald Trump doesn’t think he can run on a record because it’s a failed record, Joe Biden on that stage said, Hey, just please vote.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: So I’ll repeat what Joe said.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Please vote.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you, Senator.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Vice president Pence, president Trump has several times refused to commit himself to a peaceful transfer of power after the election.
speaker: Susan Page

text: If vice president Biden is declared the winner and president Trump refuses to accept a peaceful transfer of power, what would be your role and responsibility as vice president?
speaker: Susan Page

text: What would you personally do?
speaker: Susan Page

text: You have two minutes.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Well, Susan, first and foremost, I think we’re going to win this election.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Because while Joe Biden and Kamala Harris rattle off a long litany of the establishment in Washington, DC and establishment that Joe Biden’s been a part of for 47 years, president Donald Trump has as launched a movement of everyday Americans from every walk of life.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And I have every confidence that the same Americans that delivered that historic victory in 2016, they see this president’s record where we rebuild our military.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: We revived our economy through tax cuts and rolling back regulation, fighting for fair trade, unleashing American energy.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: We appointed conservatives to our federal courts at every level.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And we stood with the men and women of law enforcement every single day.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And I think that movement of Americans has only grown stronger in the last four years.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But when you talk about accepting the outcome of the election, I must tell you.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Senator, your party has spent the last three and a half years trying to overturn the results of the last election.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: It’s amazing.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: When Joe Biden was vice president of the United States, the FBI actually spied on president Trump and my campaign.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I mean, there were documents released this week that the CIA actually made a referral to the FBI, documenting that those allegations were coming from the Hillary Clinton campaign.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And of course, we’ve all seen the avalanche, what you put the country through for the better part of three years, until it was found that there was no obstruction, no collusion, case closed.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And then Senator Harris, you and your colleagues in the Congress tried to impeach the president of the United States over a phone call.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And now Hillary Clinton has actually said to Joe Biden that, in her words, under no circumstances, should he concede the election.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: So let me just say, I think we’re going to win this election.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: President Trump and I are fighting every day in courthouses to prevent Joe Biden and Kamala Harris from changing the rules and creating this universal mail in voting that’ll create a massive opportunity for voter fraud.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And we have a free and fair election.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: We know we’re going to have confidence in it.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And I believe in all my heart that president Donald Trump is going to be reelected for four more years.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I’ve written all the questions that I’ve asked tonight, but for the final question of the debate, I’d like to read a question that someone else wrote.
speaker: Susan Page

text: The Utah Debate Commission asked students in the state to write essays about what they would like to ask you.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And I want to close tonight’s debate with the question posed by Brecklin Brown.
speaker: Susan Page

text: She’s an eighth grader at Springville Junior High in Springville, Utah.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And here’s what she wrote.
speaker: Susan Page

text: “When I watch the news, all I see is arguing between Democrats and Republicans.
speaker: Susan Page

text: When I watch the news, all I see is citizen fighting against citizen.
speaker: Susan Page

text: When I watch the news, all I see are two candidates from opposing parties trying to tear each other down.
speaker: Susan Page

text: If our leaders can’t get along, how are the citizens supposed to get along?” And then she added, “Your examples could make all the difference to bring us together.” So to each of you in turn, I’d like you to take one minute and respond to Brecklin.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Vice president Pence, you have one minute.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Brecklin, it’s a wonderful question.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And let me just commend you for taking an interest in public life.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I started following the news when I was very young.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And in America, we believe in a free and open exchange of debate.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And we celebrate that.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: It’s how we’ve created literally the freest and most prosperous nation in the history of the world.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I would tell you that, don’t assume that what you’re seeing on your local news networks is synonymous with the American people.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I look at the relationship between Justice Ruth Bader Ginsberg, the late justice who we just lost from the Supreme Court, and the late justice Antonin Scalia.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: They were on polar opposites on the Supreme Court of the United States.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: One very liberal one, very conservative.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But what’s been learned since her passing was the two of them and their families were the very closest of friends.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Here in America, we can disagree.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: We can debate vigorously as Senator Harris and I have on this stage tonight.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But when the debate is over, we come together as Americans.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And that’s what people do, in big cities and small towns all across this country.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: So I just want to encourage you, Brecklin.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: I want to tell you that we’re going to work every day to have government as good as our people, and the American people each and every day.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Love a good debate.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: We love a good argument.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: But we always come together and are always there for one another in times of need.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: And we’ve especially learned that through the difficulties of this year.
speaker: Mike Pence

text: Thank you, vice president.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Senator Harris, what would you say to Brecklin?
speaker: Susan Page

text: First of all, I love hearing from our young leaders.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And when I hear her words, when I hear your words, Brecklin, I know our future is bright because it is that perspective on who we are and who we should be that is a sign of leadership, and is something we should all aspire to be.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And brings me to Joe, Joe Biden.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: One of the reasons that Joe decided to run for president is after Charlottesville, which we talked about earlier.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: It so troubled him and upset him like it did all of us, that there was that kind of hate and division.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: What propelled Joe to run for president was to see that over the course of the last four years, what Brecklin described has been happening.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Joe has a longstanding reputation of working across the aisle, and working in a bipartisan way.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And that’s what he’s going to do as president.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Joe Biden has a history of lifting people up and fighting for their dignity.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: You have to know Joe’s story to know that Joe has known pain.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: He has known suffering.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And he has known love.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Brecklin, when you think about the future, I do believe the future is bright.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And it will be because of your leadership, and it will be because we fight for each person’s voice through their vote.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: And we get engaged in this election, because you have the ability through your work and through, eventually, your vote, to determine the future of our country and what its leadership looks like.
speaker: Kamala Harris

text: Thank you, Senator Harris.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Thank you, vice president Pence.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Thank you so much for being with us tonight.
speaker: Susan Page

text: We want to thank also the University of Utah for its hospitality.
speaker: Susan Page

text: And most of all, our thanks to all the Americans who watched this debate tonight.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Again, our best wishes for a quick recovery to president Trump, the First Lady, and everyone who is battling COVID-19.
speaker: Susan Page

text: The second presidential debate is next week on October 15, a town hall style debate in Miami.
speaker: Susan Page

text: We hope you’ll join us then.
speaker: Susan Page

text: Good evening.
